It may be used freely by individuals for research, teaching, and personal use as long as this statement of availability is included in the text. For all other use contact the Special Collections Librarian, Hoskins Library, University of Tennessee, 1401 Cumberland Avenue, Knoxville, TN 37996. (865) 974-4480.

bibl.title: [Letter] 1797 Jun. 28, Knoxville [Tennessee, to] Jesse Payne, Little Limestone [Tennessee] / Nath[anie]l Cowan
bibl.author: Cowan, Nathaniel
bibl.note: This is a letter from Nathaniel Cowan to Jesse Payne, dated June 28, 1797. Cowan is reporting about a shipment of flour and whiskey that he has recently received from Payne, via a Mr. Young.

projectDesc.p: Created for the University of Tennessee Digital Library

editorialDecl.p: Quotation marks retained as data except inside q tags
Errors in transcription of the printed text controlled with X-Metal 2.1 spell-checker; text has also been thoroughly proofread.
Corrections and normalization represented by editorial tags.
Catchwords and directional notes such as "turn page over" have been omitted.

refsDecl.p: ID attributes provided for only those pages, chapters, or illustrations toward which a reference or figure points.

div1.p: I Received your friendly Letter together with the flower you Say you weiged twenty Hundred & fifteen weight which I thank you for your Trouble you Say you Sent one hundred & four Gallons of whiskey By Mr young one cast was enjured in the Carrage and I had it measured and there was Just forty Gallons of it and the other Cask is not Sufficient for to hold it I will Take what Came I Can of it and not Let it be last and will princley obay your Directions by it Mr young Says he will pay you for what is Lost of the whiskey Ive you Say you will be Down I would be glad to See you hear & if you Cannot Come Down Send a letter when I must be up as you wright me

closer.salute:
I & Brothers famely is well no more
I am thy friend whilest
